description:
Aegilops tauschii subsp. strangulata is a subspecies of a wild wheat grass species known as Aegilops tauschii. It is a grassy plant that is native to parts of Central Asia, including regions of Iran, Afghanistan, and Pakistan.

This subspecies is characterized by its slender, cylindrical spikes that are typically 6-10 cm long. The spikelets, which are the small, individual flower-bearing units along the spike, are usually 3-4 flowered and have a short, strangulated rachis (the central stem of the spike). The glumes, or the small, scale-like structures at the base of each spikelet, are narrow and pointed.

Aegilops tauschii subsp. strangulata is considered an important genetic resource for wheat breeding, as it is a wild relative of cultivated wheat. It has been used to introduce desirable traits, such as disease resistance and abiotic stress tolerance, into modern wheat varieties through hybridization and introgression techniques.
